div1.head: Minutes of the annual meeting of the Board of Managers of the Walter Reed Memorial Association, November 19, 1945
div1.p:
MINUTES
of the
Annual Meeting of the Board of Managers of the Walter Reed Memorial
Association held at Washington, D. C., November 19, 1945

The Board of Managers met in the Library, Trust Department, American Security and Trust
Company, 15th St. and Pennsylvania Ave., N.W., at 10:30 A.M. and was called to order
by its President, Brig. Gen. Jefferson R. Kean.

Present: Brig. Gen. J. R. Kean; Major Gen. M. W. Ireland; Admiral E. R. Stitt; Brig.
Gen. F. R. Keefer; Brig. Gen. A. G. Love; Mr. Hans W. Ireland; Col. J. F. Siler.
Absent: Major Gen. C. R. Reynolds; Mr. Gilbert Grosvenor; Dr. L. O. Howard.
The minutes of the last meeting were read, approved and ordered made of record.

The Treasurer presented his annual report showing in summary comparative income
and disbursements for the fiscal years ending Oct. 31, 1944 and Oct. 31, 1945 and the
market value of the capital investments of the Memorial Fund as of Oct. 31, 1944 and
Oct. 31, 1945, as follows:

div1.p: The report of the Treasurer was approved.

The following officers were elected for the forthcoming year:
President Brig. Gen. Jefferson R. Kean
Vice President Major Gen. M. W. Ireland
Secretary Colonel Joseph F. Siler
Treasurer Mr. Hans W. Ireland

The Secretary, Colonel Siler, stated that in sending out the minutes of the last
annual meeting to the members of the Board of Managers, he had sent a covering letter
to those members who were absent last year, requesting that, after reviewing the dis-
cussion relative to the eventual disposition of the memorial fund as a “living” memor-
ial on the one hand or a “visible” statue, on the other, they express their opinion
in the premises. In reply, the following opinions were expressed. Dr. L. O. Howard -
“I vote for the use of the endowment or its income for suitable scientific purposes.”
Col. Julian M. Cabell - “As to the form of the memorial, I have had no experience in
such things but quite approve your suggestion that the income should be used for sci-
entific research.”

The opinion expressed by Maj. Gen. C. R. Reynolds is incorporated in the follow-
ing extracts from a letter received from him:

"My thought in the matter is that a fund of this size, approximately $25,000, is
altogether too insignificant to furnish an income that will be of consequence in the
field of medical research, nor am I certain that it is enough to build a monument to
Walter Reed. Consequently, I would favor a movement at the present time to provide a
much larger fund which I think might well be successful now, or immediately after the
war, because of the great interest in preventive medicine and tropical diseases among
a greatly increased military population as well as the general public. If, however,
I am asked, as I assume I have been, for my opinion as to the best use of a fund of
$25,000 I would say that a visible monument or memorial should be erected in the City
of Washington in memory of Walter Reed. I do not recall that there is any monument in
the District of Columbia to a doctor, except the one to Hahnemann and one's memory
has to be scratched to think of any monument, except the John B. Murphy Memorial at the
American College of Surgeons and several now projected, throughout the whole United
States.

“I know I am dissenting from the opinion of those who knew Walter Reed personally
and more about his work than I do, but I am strongly of the opinion that $1,000 or
more yearly, no matter how it is expended, will not adequately recall or memorialize
the services of this great man.”

Colonel Siler pointed out that the present market value of the endowment fund was
$35,000 rather than $25,00 and, though the annual income is now only approximately
$1000, it was his experience that such an amount could be used to profit and advantage
in the prosecuation of scientific research, particularly so as it would continue from
year to year. Furthermore, it might be practicable eventually to allow the income to
accumulate over a period of years, thus adding to the endowment with eventual material
increase in income.

In the course of the discussion it was pointed out that the Army General Hospital
in Washington was named for Walter Reed to honor his memory and that doubtless in the
years to come the name “Walter Reed General Hospital” would much better serve to keep
the name and achievements of Walter Reed fresh in the minds and hearts of the people
than would any statue erected in Washington. In this connection, Admiral Stitt stated
that a number of years ago a statue of Benjamin Rush was erected in what is now the
Naval Observatory reservation on Massachusetts Avenue and he wondered how many of those
m -2-
present at the meeting had any knowledge of the existence of such a memorial. As a
matter of fact, only Admiral Stitt, General Ireland and General Kean had seen or knew
of its existence.

The members of the Board present reiterated the opinion expressed at the last
annual meeting to the effect that eventually the capital assets should constitute an
endowment, the income of which should be used for the prosecution of suitable medical
research.

General Keefer expressed the very deep regret of the members of the Board at the
loss of one of its members, Col. Julian M. Cabell, whose death had occurred at Walter
Reed General Hospital last week.

Motion was made by Colonel Siler that Dr. Philip S. Hench, of the Mayo Clinic,
now on active duty as a Col., M.C., A.U.S. at the Army and Navy General Hospital,
Hot Springs, be elected as a member of the Board of Managers to succeed Colonel Cabell,
deceased. This motion was seconded and carried unanimously.

There being no further business, the meeting adjourned to meet at the call of the
President.
